bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, June 26, 1938

div1.p: Moran comments on the film “Yellow Jack” and returns autographed photographs of himself. He criticizes Kissinger for enjoying the spotlight and mentions that his Congressional Medal will go to the University of Virginia.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, June 26, 1938
div1.opener:
Havana, June 26, 1938.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Please accept my most humble apologies for failing to reply
to your own letter dated March 7th and to that of your Secretary, dated
March 24th. I have had my hands full between the duties of my office
on one hand and correspondence with reference to “Yellow Jack” on the
other. By this time, you have probably seen “Yellow Jack” in the
movies. If so, I will appreciate your opinion as to the part which
your humble servant plays therein as “Sergeant O'Hara”, impersonated by
Robert Montgomery. When MGM wrote me for permission to use my name
in connection with the filmed version of “Yellow Jack”, the company wrote
me at the same time for whatever information I could give as to the per-
sonality of Dr. Finlay. About the same time the Havana papers were
carrying on a campaign which roundly condemned the film, then under
production, many of the articles claiming that Dr. Finlay was not even
mentioned. To the end that local agitation might be allayed I pointed
out to the producers that, unless the part played by Finlay in the picture
was such as to satisfy Cuban sentiment, at least to a reasonable degree,
the picture might face a boycott in Cuba and in other Latin-American
countries. The decision to film “Yellow Jack” was apparently carried
on by MGM with great haste, once the company decided to film it. The
matter had been pending decision for over a year and when the company
finally decided that “Yellow Jack” might be successfully filmed, action
was rapid. It appears that it was before the camera for only six weeks
as against three to six months before the camera for pictures of its now
accepted category. The critics appear to be unanimous in pronouncing
it one of the best pictures of the year, so far. One critic, writing in
the July number of “Red Book” gives one the idea, reading between the lines,
that although the picture cost only half a million dollars to film, it is
in a class with pictures costing one to two million. I understand that
MGM, based on recommendations made by me and others, spent an additional
twenty thousand in reforming the parts of Finlay and Agramonte. Such
reforms, so I am told is for Latin-American consumption only. It is
rather unfortunate that Dr. Finlay, impersonated by Charles Coburn,
appears wearing a monocle. He wore spectacles, which is far from being
the same thing. The excuse given by MGM is that Charles Coburn, due to
a defect in one eye, habitually wear a monocle. That explanation is not
accepted in entire good faith by the Cubans, however, but talk of boycott-
ing the picture has died down. It will not come to Cuba before the end of
August or the first week of September, so I am informed by the local manager
of MGM. I am to have a preview of the picture as soon as it reaches
Havana. Was invited to Washington for the opening performance but side-
stepped the honor of being presented on the Stage for a bow. My fellow
guinea pig, Kissinger, was there with “bells on” and was feted and made
much of. He grows fat on publicity. I get thin on it. The manager of
Loew's theatre in the Capitol City gave the critics the idea that Kissinger
was none other than Sergeant O'Hara. Well, so far as I am concerned, that
is fair enough. It was good propaganda for MGM and made Kissinger the idol
of Washington for a week. My friends there resent more than I do the steal-
ing of the show by Kissinger. I am informed that Robert Montgomery talks
for me in a rich Irish brogue. James Stewart who played the part in the
original stage presentation had a thicker brogue than I have ever been able
to claim.

With reference to the photos you sent ffor dedication and
signature. I regret to state that I am not very well satisfied with
their appearnce, after dedicating them to you on the face of the
photographs. However, I am sending them to you. I used “Quink”
(Parker) in writing and am far from satisfied with the finished product.
Presumably there is a special ink or pencil for dedication of photographs
but I used my fountain pen and the ink which I always use for signing
current correspondence, etc. etc. If you do not like the photos in
their present form, please let me know and I will have another taken for
you and send you one of the regular photographs I had taken with dedication
on the back on the black print and on the mounting for the brown finish.

I am curious to know if you ever read your paper for the Mayo
Clinic which you had in mind when you originally wrote to me. With refer-
ence to Dr. Crenshaw. It was foolish of me to think that he would
remember me. We were classmates for one year only and he was not one of
those whom I intimately knew. I think the best thing we can do is to
forget all about one another since we have but one thing in common, viz:
that we are both members of the UVA Alumnae. I do not now recall whether or
not I told you in one of my previous letters that my Congressional Medal
will eventually go to the University of Virginia. I want to make sure
that it will not become lost in the shuffle. That chance I would have to
take, of course, if a kindly Providence had favored me with a son or
daughter.

Thank you very much for remembering me while you were abroad.
I appreciate the postcard you sent me very much. I could keep on writing
to the end of this page but my bettr half has just phoned me that I am due
at home for dinner, this being Sunday. Kindly let me hear from you soon
and remember that I have no secretary to write my letters for me. This in
case you should feel that I take a long time to answer your letters.
With kindest personal regards, I remain,
div1.closer:
Yours most sincerely, John J. Moran Address:
John J. Moran,
